content: From Hanson: ". . . The Greek comic playwright Aristophanes once described how screaming politicians - posing as men of the people - would sway Athenian citizens by offering them all sort of perks and goodies that the government had no idea how to pay for. "The historian Thucydides offers even more frightening accounts of bloodthirsty voters after they were aroused by demagogues ("leaders or drivers of the people"). One day, in bloodthirsty rage, voters demanded the death of the rebellious men of the subject island city of Mytilene; yet on the very next, in sudden remorse, they rescinded that blanket death sentence. . ." Jackass party destructiveness and pussilanimosity at its finest.

content: That was beautiful. Tragic, of course - as is the hallmark of all Greek Novels; but beautiful nonetheless. I can only say that I'm reminded of Neo-Conservative mobs led by Sarah Palin as she would whip them up into a far-right lather: "kill him", "kill the muslim Obama", "kill the terrorist sympathizer". Quite a sight to behold... And yes, quite tragic also...

content: One wonders whether the originator of that bit of genius has ever read any Aristophanes (not a tragedian by any means Boazjones, the father of satire in fact) or Thucydides for that matter. Of the former I reckon The Knights and The Acharnians might be most relevant although Lysistrata might also have something to say. While one could apply the themes to the present administration they might equally be applied to the previous one. As for Thucydides' one can certainly see echoes of the Athenian relationship with the Delian League in how the Bush Administration treated it's allies at times. Besides, what is Rush Limbaugh if not a demagogue - not possibly as openly bloodthirsty as Cleon or Alcibiades but certainly a man who tries to tell the demos what to think.

content: quote: This is why our fore-fathers made us a republic rather than a democracy, they had just seen the French fall to this type of foolery Speaking of education, someone evidently failed history. The US Constitution was ratified and in effect as of March 1789. The Estates General didn't convene until May 1789, and the Bastille wasn't stormed (first overt act of the French revolution) until July of that year. In other words, the American Republic predated the French Revolution, both in idea and implementation. Sullivan013
quote: This is why our fore-fathers made us a republic rather than a democracy, they had just seen the French fall to this type of foolery
reply: Speaking of education, someone evidently failed history. The US Constitution was ratified and in effect as of March 1789. The Estates General didn't convene until May 1789, and the Bastille wasn't stormed (first overt act of the French revolution) until July of that year. In other words, the American Republic predated the French Revolution, both in idea and implementation. Sullivan013
